name: Foundations & Modeling
summary: Canonical abstractions (ER diagrams, relations, relational algebra) that separate logical from physical design.

name: Relational Model
summary: Relations, tuples, keys, and integrity constraints describing data as mathematics.

name: Relational Algebra
summary: Sigma/pi/join/set operators that provide a procedural semantics for SQL.

name: SQL Language
summary: Declarative data definition/manipulation statements derived from relational algebra.

name: Schema Design & Normalization
summary: Functional dependencies, normal forms, and selective denormalization to balance integrity vs. performance.

name: Functional Dependencies
summary: Attribute determinism rules that shape candidate keys and decomposition choices.

name: Normal Forms
summary: 1NF through BCNF plus practical heuristics for when to denormalize.

name: Execution & Storage
summary: Physical layout, indexing, and query processing internals.

name: Storage Engines
summary: Heap files, log-structured tables, slotted pages, and buffer management.

name: Indexing Strategies
summary: B+-trees, hash, bitmap, and GiST indexes plus maintenance costs.

name: Query Planning & Optimization
summary: Cost models, statistics, and plan enumeration via Selinger- and Volcano-style search.

name: Cost Models & Cardinality Estimation
summary: Statistics, histograms, and heuristics used to estimate join order cost.

name: Logging & Recovery
summary: Write-ahead logs, checkpoints, and ARIES-style redo/undo to guarantee durability.

name: Transactions & Concurrency
summary: Guarantees that keep shared data correct when multiple writers/readers interact.

name: Transaction Management
summary: ACID semantics, atomic commit boundaries, and application-facing APIs.

name: Concurrency Control
summary: Two-phase locking, timestamp ordering, optimistic control, and conflict handling.

name: Multi-Version Concurrency Control
summary: Snapshot isolation using version chains and garbage collection windows.

name: Locking & Recovery Coordination
summary: Lock management, deadlock detection, WAL interactions, and logical vs. physical logging.

name: Distributed & Replicated Systems
summary: Scale-out topologies, consensus, and geo-distributed SQL.

name: Replication & Sharding
summary: Leader/follower, multi-leader, and partitioning schemes for scale and resilience.

name: Distributed Transactions
summary: Two-phase commit, Paxos/Raft, and deterministic ordering (TrueTime).

name: TrueTime & External Consistency
summary: Using bounded clock uncertainty to guarantee global ordering.

name: Consistency Models
summary: Linearizability, sequential and eventual consistency, CAP/PACELC trade-offs.

name: CAP Theorem
summary: Under partitions, systems trade availability against consistency.

name: NoSQL Models
summary: Column-family, document, and key-value stores optimized for targeted workloads.

name: Modern Data Infrastructure
summary: Cloud-native analytics, HTAP, streaming, and governance.

name: Cloud Data Warehouses
summary: Shared-nothing MPP warehouses with elastic compute/storage separation.

name: Hybrid Transactional/Analytical Processing (HTAP)
summary: Systems blending OLTP + analytics via log-based replication and materialized views.

name: Streaming Analytics
summary: Event-driven pipelines (Kafka, Beam) and incremental view maintenance.

name: Governance & Lineage
summary: Catalogs, lineage tracking, and reproducibility controls ensuring provenance.

prompt: Given Relations Orders(order_id, customer_id, total) and Customers(customer_id, region), write SQL to return each region with average order total for customers placing >=5 orders.
answer_sketch: SELECT c.region, AVG(o.total) ... GROUP BY c.region HAVING COUNT(*) >= 5

prompt: A table Campaign(channel, campaign_id, region, manager, region_manager_email) exhibits repeated manager info. Show how to reach BCNF and justify the functional dependencies you used.
answer_sketch: Identify region -> (manager, email); decompose into Campaign + RegionManager tables.

prompt: Explain how strict two-phase locking prevents dirty reads yet can deadlock. Provide a concrete deadlock example and mitigation.
answer_sketch: Transactions acquire X locks and hold until commit; cycle via T1 lock A then waiting on B while T2 holds B, waiting on A.

prompt: During crash recovery, outline ARIES's Analysis, Redo, and Undo phases and describe the role of LSNs and compensation log records.
answer_sketch: Analysis rebuilds dirty page table + txn table; Redo repeats history; Undo uses CLRs for winner txns.

prompt: A cross-region key-value store must remain available during network partitions. According to CAP, which trade-offs are forced and what compensating techniques can preserve developer sanity?
answer_sketch: Availability + partition tolerance imply relaxing consistency (eventual). Use version vectors, CRDTs, or client reconciliation.

prompt: Contrast event-time vs. processing-time windows in unified streaming/batch APIs like Beam. Provide a use case where watermarks lag but correctness must be maintained.
answer_sketch: Event-time windows keyed by data timestamps; late data handled via allowed lateness/trigger updates.

Select index types for different workload shapes.
Diagnose plan regressions via cardinality estimates.
Relate ACID properties to application-level invariants.
Contrast locking, MVCC, and optimistic control.
